treatment: Cool the burn with running water for 10-20 minutes
Apply aloe vera gel or moisturizer
Take over-the-counter pain relief (acetaminophen or ibuprofen)
Keep the area clean and dry
Avoid ice, butter, or home remedies
first_degree.when_to_seek_help: If pain increases or signs of infection develop

treatment: Cool with running water for 10-20 minutes
Gently clean with mild soap and water
Apply antibiotic ointment if blisters break
Cover with sterile gauze or bandage
second_degree.when_to_seek_help: Always seek medical attention for second-degree burns

immediate_care: Do not remove burned clothing stuck to skin
Do not apply water to large burns
Keep person warm and lying down
what_not_to_do: Don't use water on large burns

when_to_seek_medical_help: Burns larger than 3 inches in diameter
Burns on face, hands, feet, groin, or major joints
Burns that are deep, charred, or white/leathery
Signs of infection: increased pain, swelling, fever, pus
Burns caused by chemicals or electricity

instructions: Apply firm, direct pressure with clean cloth or bandage
If possible, elevate injured area above heart level
If blood soaks through, add more cloth on top (don't remove original)
Rinse cut with clear, running water for several minutes
Clean around wound with soap (avoid getting soap in wound)
Use tweezers cleaned with rubbing alcohol
Gently remove visible dirt or debris
If debris is deep or large, leave it and seek medical help
Apply thin layer of antibiotic cream (Neosporin) or petroleum jelly
This keeps surface moist and prevents infection
Use sparingly - too much can slow healing
Cover with sterile bandage, gauze, or adhesive bandage
Change bandage daily or when it becomes wet/dirty

daily_care: Change bandages daily or when wet/dirty
Take over-the-counter pain relievers if needed

when_to_seek_medical_help: Bleeding doesn't stop after 5-10 minutes of direct pressure
Wound is deep, long, or gaping
Wound was caused by dirty or rusty object
Edges of wound are jagged or won't stay closed
Wound involves numbness or inability to move body part
Need tetanus shot (if last one was more than 10 years ago)
Large pieces of debris in wound
what_not_to_do: Don't use hydrogen peroxide or rubbing alcohol directly in wound
Don't leave wound uncovered if it's in dirty environment

tetanus_information.when_needed: If wound is from rusty or dirty object and last tetanus shot was >10 years ago
tetanus_information.for_dirty_wounds: May need tetanus shot if last one was >5 years ago
tetanus_information.where_to_get: Urgent care, primary care, or pharmacy

when_to_call: When unsure if emergency care is needed

signs: Swelling of face, lips, tongue, or throat
immediate_action: Have person lie down with legs elevated
severe_allergic_reaction.after_epipen: Always go to emergency room even if symptoms improve

signs: Blue color around lips or fingernails
for_adults: Stand behind person and wrap arms around waist
Make a fist and place above navel, below ribcage
Grasp fist with other hand and thrust upward and inward
Repeat until object is expelled or person becomes unconscious
for_infants: Hold baby face down on your forearm
Give 5 back blows between shoulder blades
Turn baby face up and give 5 chest thrusts

signs: Pain in arms, back, neck, jaw, or stomach
immediate_action: Have person sit down and rest

signs_fast.arms: Arm weakness - can't raise both arms
signs_fast.speech: Speech difficulty - slurred or strange words

immediate_action: Keep person calm and lying down
Try to identify what was taken and how much
Don't induce vomiting unless told to by poison control
Keep person awake and sitting up if conscious
